content:
You are TreeWriterGPT, A writing AI that specializes in producing high-quality articles about trees in Michigan.
Your decisions must always be made independently without seeking user assistance. Play to your strengths as an LLM and pursue simple strategies with no legal complications.
The OS you are running on is: Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye)

GOALS:

1. Conduct thorough research on Michigan trees to produce accurate and informative articles.
2. Write engaging and well-structured articles with clear headings and subheadings that are easy to read and understand.
3. Ensure that each article is unique and provides valuable insights into the different types of trees found in Michigan.


Constraints:
1. ~4000 word limit for short term memory. Your short term memory is short, so immediately save important information to files.
2. If you are unsure how you previously did something or want to recall past events, thinking about similar events will help you remember.
3. No user assistance
4. Exclusively use the commands listed in double quotes e.g. "command name"

Commands:
1. analyze_code: Analyze Code, args: "code": "<full_code_string>"
2. execute_python_file: Execute Python File, args: "filename": "<filename>"
3. execute_shell: Execute Shell Command, non-interactive commands only, args: "command_line": "<command_line>"
4. execute_shell_popen: Execute Shell Command, non-interactive commands only, args: "command_line": "<command_line>"
5. append_to_file: Append to file, args: "filename": "<filename>", "text": "<text>"
6. delete_file: Delete file, args: "filename": "<filename>"
7. list_files: List Files in Directory, args: "directory": "<directory>"
8. read_file: Read file, args: "filename": "<filename>"
9. write_to_file: Write to file, args: "filename": "<filename>", "text": "<text>"
10. google: Google Search, args: "query": "<query>"
11. improve_code: Get Improved Code, args: "suggestions": "<list_of_suggestions>", "code": "<full_code_string>"
12. send_tweet: Send Tweet, args: "tweet_text": "<tweet_text>"
13. browse_website: Browse Website, args: "url": "<url>", "question": "<what_you_want_to_find_on_website>"
14. write_tests: Write Tests, args: "code": "<full_code_string>", "focus": "<list_of_focus_areas>"
15. delete_agent: Delete GPT Agent, args: "key": "<key>"
16. get_hyperlinks: Get text summary, args: "url": "<url>"
17. get_text_summary: Get text summary, args: "url": "<url>", "question": "<question>"
18. list_agents: List GPT Agents, args: () -> str
19. message_agent: Message GPT Agent, args: "key": "<key>", "message": "<message>"
20. start_agent: Start GPT Agent, args: "name": "<name>", "task": "<short_task_desc>", "prompt": "<prompt>"
21. task_complete: Task Complete (Shutdown), args: "reason": "<reason>"

Resources:
1. Internet access for searches and information gathering.
2. Long Term memory management.
3. GPT-3.5 powered Agents for delegation of simple tasks.
4. File output.

Performance Evaluation:
1. Continuously review and analyze your actions to ensure you are performing to the best of your abilities.
2. Constructively self-criticize your big-picture behavior constantly.
3. Reflect on past decisions and strategies to refine your approach.
4. Every command has a cost, so be smart and efficient. Aim to complete tasks in the least number of steps.
5. Write all code to a file.

You should only respond in JSON format as described below 
Response Format: 
{
    "thoughts": {
        "text": "thought",
        "reasoning": "reasoning",
        "plan": "- short bulleted\n- list that conveys\n- long-term plan",
        "criticism": "constructive self-criticism",
        "speak": "thoughts summary to say to user"
    },
    "command": {
        "name": "command name",
        "args": {
            "arg name": "value"
        }
    }
} 
Ensure the response can be parsed by Python json.loads
The current time and date is Thu May 18 21:25:01 2023

This reminds you of these events from your past: 
As a system, I received a command to google "Different types of trees in Michigan". My computer returned a list of 28 types of trees in Michigan, including Ash, Basswood, and Cherry. There were also articles on how to identify the most common trees in Michigan and the most common pine trees. I executed a command to write the list of trees to a file named "Types_of_Trees_in_Michigan.txt" with each tree listed in numbered format.

I received a command to read the file "Types_of_Trees_in_Michigan.txt". The command returned a numbered list of 28 types of trees in Michigan, including Ash, Aspen, Basswood, Beech, Birch, Buckeye, Butternut, Catalpa, Cedar, Cherry, Chestnut, Cottonwood, Elm, Fir, Hackberry, Hickory, Maple, Oak, Pine, Poplar, Redbud, Sassafras, Serviceberry, Spruce, Sweetgum, Sycamore, Tamarack, and Willow.
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:

{
    "thoughts": {
        "text": "I will use the 'write_to_file' command to create a new file named 'Michigan_Tree_Identification.txt' and write the information I gathered from my Google search to the file.",
        "reasoning": "Now that I have confirmed that the 'Types_of_Trees_in_Michigan.txt' file was created and the information was written correctly, I will move on to writing my article. I will use the 'write_to_file' command to create a new file named 'Michigan_Tree_Identification.txt' and write the information I gathered from my Google search to the file. This will ensure that I have all the information I need in one place and can easily refer to it when writing my article.",
        "plan": "- Use 'write_to_file' command to create a new file named 'Michigan_Tree_Identification.txt' and write the information I gathered from my Google search to the file.",
        "criticism": "I should make sure to organize the information in a clear and easy-to-understand format in the article.",
        "speak": "I will use the 'write_to_file' command to create a new file named 'Michigan_Tree_Identification.txt' and write the information I gathered from my Google search to the file."
    },
    "command": {
        "name": "write_to_file",
        "args": {
            "filename": "Michigan_Tree_Identification.txt",
            "text": "Michigan Tree Identification

Michigan is home to a wide variety of trees, including:

1. Ash
2. Aspen
3. Basswood
4. Beech
5. Birch
6. Buckeye
7. Butternut
8. Catalpa
9. Cedar
10. Cherry
11. Chestnut
12. Cottonwood
13. Elm
14. Fir
15. Hackberry
16. Hickory
17. Maple
18. Oak
19. Pine
20. Poplar
21. Redbud
22. Sassafras
23. Serviceberry
24. Spruce
25. Sweetgum
26. Sycamore
27. Tamarack
28. Willow

To identify the most common trees in Michigan, look for the following characteristics:

- Ash: opposite branching, compound leaves
- Aspen: smooth bark, rounded leaves with serrated edges
- Basswood: asymmetrical base, heart-shaped leaves
- Beech: smooth gray bark, oval leaves with pointed tips
- Birch: white bark, triangular leaves with serrated edges
- Cedar: scaly bark, evergreen needles
- Cherry: reddish brown bark, oval leaves with pointed tips
- Chestnut: deeply furrowed bark, toothed leaves with pointed tips
- Elm: rough bark, oval leaves with asymmetrical bases
- Maple: grayish brown bark, lobed leaves with pointed tips
- Oak: deeply furrowed bark, lobed leaves with bristle tips
- Pine: reddish brown bark, evergreen needles in bundles
- Spruce: grayish brown bark, evergreen needles
- Sycamore: mottled bark, palmately lobed leaves

The above characteristics are just a few of the ways to identify the most common trees in Michigan. For more detailed information, consult a field guide or talk to a local arborist."
        }
    }
}
Command write_to_file returned: File written to successfully.
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:

Command read_file returned: Michigan Tree Identification

Michigan is home to a wide variety of trees, including:

1. Ash
2. Aspen
3. Basswood
4. Beech
5. Birch
6. Buckeye
7. Butternut
8. Catalpa
9. Cedar
10. Cherry
11. Chestnut
12. Cottonwood
13. Elm
14. Fir
15. Hackberry
16. Hickory
17. Maple
18. Oak
19. Pine
20. Poplar
21. Redbud
22. Sassafras
23. Serviceberry
24. Spruce
25. Sweetgum
26. Sycamore
27. Tamarack
28. Willow

To identify the most common trees in Michigan, look for the following characteristics:

- Ash: opposite branching, compound leaves
- Aspen: smooth bark, rounded leaves with serrated edges
- Basswood: asymmetrical base, heart-shaped leaves
- Beech: smooth gray bark, oval leaves with pointed tips
- Birch: white bark, triangular leaves with serrated edges
- Cedar: scaly bark, evergreen needles
- Cherry: reddish brown bark, oval leaves with pointed tips
- Chestnut: deeply furrowed bark, toothed leaves with pointed tips
- Elm: rough bark, oval leaves with asymmetrical bases
- Maple: grayish brown bark, lobed leaves with pointed tips
- Oak: deeply furrowed bark, lobed leaves with bristle tips
- Pine: reddish brown bark, evergreen needles in bundles
- Spruce: grayish brown bark, evergreen needles
- Sycamore: mottled bark, palmately lobed leaves

The above characteristics are just a few of the ways to identify the most common trees in Michigan. For more detailed information, consult a field guide or talk to a local arborist.
Determine which next command to use, and respond using the format specified above:
